questions.stem: Exercise-induced pulmonary hemorrhage (EIPH) in horses is BEST defined as:

options.label: A
options.text: Any cause of nasal bleeding in horses at rest

options.label: B
options.text: Detection of blood within the airways of horses following strenuous exercise

options.label: C
options.text: Pulmonary edema due to heart failure at rest

options.label: D
options.text: Hemorrhage confined to the pleural space after trauma

questions.explanation: EIPH is defined as the presence of blood in the airways of horses after strenuous exercise, not just any nasal bleeding at rest. Pulmonary edema, pleural hemorrhage, or trauma (C, D) have different definitions.

questions.stem: EIPH is MOST commonly recognized in which types of horses?

options.label: B
options.text: Racehorses, polo horses, barrel racers, and eventing horses that perform intense exercise

options.label: D
options.text: Draft horses used for light work

questions.explanation: EIPH is most commonly observed in horses engaged in high-intensity disciplines such as racing, polo, barrel racing, and eventing. Pasture broodmares, foals at weaning, or lightly worked drafts (A, C, D) are not the primary risk groups.

questions.stem: Overt epistaxis (“bleeder”) associated with EIPH is:

options.label: A
options.text: Very common, occurring in most cases

options.label: B
options.text: Rare, seen in only about 5% of affected horses

options.label: D
options.text: Not related to EIPH at all

questions.explanation: Overt epistaxis occurs in only about 5% of horses with EIPH, making it a relatively rare but dramatic sign. It is therefore not typical of all EIPH cases (A, C, D).

questions.stem: The primary pathophysiologic mechanism underlying EIPH is:

options.label: B
options.text: Stress failure of pulmonary capillaries due to extreme transmural pressures during intense exercise

questions.explanation: The central mechanism is stress failure of pulmonary capillary walls caused by extreme transmural pressure differences during intense exercise. Immune-mediated or infectious etiologies (A, C, D) do not explain typical EIPH.

questions.stem: Which combination of pressures contributes to capillary wall stress and rupture in EIPH?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased pulmonary vascular pressure and increased alveolar pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Increased pulmonary vascular (arterial and venous) pressures plus negative alveolar pressure

options.label: C
options.text: Constant, normal vascular and alveolar pressures

questions.explanation: High pulmonary vascular (arterial and venous) pressures combined with markedly negative alveolar pressures increase capillary wall stress to the point of rupture. The other options describe pressure states that do not match the described pathophysiology.

questions.stem: Where in the lungs are EIPH lesions most commonly found?
questions.explanation: Lesions are predominantly localized in the caudodorsal lung lobes, where blood flow is highest during intense exercise. Cranioventral or uniform distribution (A, D) is more typical of other diseases (e.g., pneumonia).

questions.stem: Chronic, repeated episodes of EIPH can lead to:

options.label: B
options.text: Venous remodeling, fibrosis, inflammation, reduced pulmonary compliance, and permanent lung damage

options.label: C
options.text: Complete lung regeneration with no residual lesions

questions.explanation: Chronic EIPH leads to venous remodeling, fibrosis, inflammation, and reduced pulmonary compliance, causing irreversible changes. Pure emphysema, perfect regeneration, or only pleural thickening (A, C, D) are not emphasized.

questions.stem: Which of the following is a recognized contributing factor that may exacerbate EIPH?

options.label: B
options.text: Upper airway obstruction such as dorsal displacement of the soft palate or laryngeal paralysis

questions.explanation: Upper airway obstructions (dorsal soft palate displacement, laryngeal paralysis), cardiac dysfunction, cold temperatures, and heritable factors can contribute to EIPH. Hyperthyroidism, rest hypothermia, or diet alone (A, C, D) are not primary listed factors.

questions.stem: Which of the following clinical signs indicates a SEVERE case of EIPH?

options.label: B
options.text: Epistaxis with visible blood at the nostrils, corresponding to Grade 4 EIPH

questions.explanation: Visible bleeding at the nostrils (epistaxis) is associated with severe EIPH (Grade 4) and is a hallmark of a serious episode. Mild cough or nasal discharge from other causes (A, C) are not specific.

questions.stem: Subclinical EIPH may present primarily as:

options.label: A
options.text: Normal athletic performance with no abnormalities

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased endurance and prolonged recovery time after exercise without visible epistaxis

questions.explanation: Subclinical EIPH often manifests as reduced stamina and prolonged recovery post-exercise, without obvious blood at the nostrils. Normal performance, colic, or rest dyspnea (A, C, D) are not typical.

questions.stem: A characteristic post-mortem finding in horses with EIPH is:

options.label: B
options.text: Hemosiderin deposits and fibrotic lesions in the caudodorsal lung lobes

questions.explanation: Post-mortem, EIPH is characterized by hemosiderin-laden macrophages and fibrotic lesions especially in caudodorsal lung regions. Abscesses, tracheal collapse, or pleural effusion alone (A, C, D) do not define EIPH.

questions.stem: What is considered the gold standard diagnostic method for EIPH in horses?

options.label: B
options.text: Endoscopy of the upper and lower airways performed 30–120 minutes post-exercise

options.label: D
options.text: Arterial blood gas analysis at rest

questions.explanation: Endoscopy 30–120 minutes after intense exercise is the gold standard diagnostic tool, allowing direct visualization and grading of tracheobronchial bleeding. Radiographs or blood gases (A, D) are less sensitive and specific.

questions.stem: The standard endoscopic grading system for EIPH evaluates:

options.label: B
options.text: Amount of tracheal bleeding from Grade 0 (none) to Grade 4 (extensive pooling and coverage)

questions.explanation: The standard grading (0–4) assesses the amount and distribution of blood in the trachea, from none (0) to pooling and near-complete coverage (4). Edema, bronchospasm, or nasal discharge (A, C, D) are not directly graded.

questions.stem: Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) in EIPH is used primarily to:

options.label: B
options.text: Confirm the presence of red blood cells and hemosiderophages in lower airway samples

questions.explanation: BAL is used to demonstrate RBCs and hemosiderophages, helping confirm EIPH even when endoscopy is negative or delayed. It does not primarily test CO2, pneumonia, or laryngeal disease (A, C, D).

questions.stem: Which diagnostic techniques have limited value for diagnosing EIPH but may show caudodorsal lung opacities?
questions.explanation: Thoracic radiography and ultrasound have limited sensitivity/specificity for EIPH but may show caudodorsal opacities. Advanced imaging, echocardiography, or skin biopsies (B–D) are not routine for this purpose.

questions.stem: Which conditions are important DIFFERENTIAL diagnoses for epistaxis in performance horses?

options.label: B
options.text: Ethmoid hematoma, guttural pouch mycosis, fungal granuloma, and pulmonary abscess or neoplasia

questions.explanation: Important differentials for epistaxis and airway bleeding include ethmoid hematoma, guttural pouch mycosis, fungal granuloma, and pulmonary abscess or neoplasia. Colic or tendon injuries (A, D) are unrelated.

questions.stem: Horses with Grade ≥2 EIPH are how likely to perform compared to unaffected horses?

options.label: A
options.text: Performance is unaffected by EIPH severity

options.label: B
options.text: They are about 4× less likely to win and 2× less likely to place in the top three

options.label: D
options.text: They are only slightly less likely to finish a race

questions.explanation: Data indicate that horses with Grade ≥2 EIPH are about four times less likely to win and twice less likely to place in the top three, demonstrating significant impact on performance. Saying performance is unaffected (A) is incorrect.

questions.stem: Which of the following is a recognized RISK FACTOR for EIPH in racehorses?

options.label: B
options.text: Higher exercise intensity and cumulative racing volume, steeplechasing/hurdling, male sex, age, and cold ambient temperatures

questions.explanation: Higher speed/intensity, racing versus training, greater cumulative racing volume, steeplechasing/hurdling, male sex, age, and cold temperatures all increase risk. Low intensity or pasture rest (A, D) decrease risk.

questions.stem: Furosemide (Lasix) is used in EIPH management primarily because it:

options.label: A
options.text: Acts as an antibiotic targeting respiratory bacteria

options.label: B
options.text: Is a loop diuretic that reduces blood volume and pulmonary pressures, with bronchodilatory and venodilatory effects

options.label: C
options.text: Increases coagulation factors in the blood

questions.explanation: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that reduces blood volume and pulmonary vascular pressures and has broncho- and venodilatory effects, lowering capillary rupture risk. It is not an antibiotic or a cure (A, D).

questions.stem: An appropriate dosing regimen for furosemide in horses to reduce EIPH severity is:

options.label: B
options.text: 0.5–1 mg/kg IV given 2–4 hours prior to strenuous exercise

options.label: D
options.text: 10 mg/kg IM at the start gate

questions.explanation: A typical regimen is 0.5–1 mg/kg IV administered 2–4 hours before strenuous exercise. The other dosages and routes do not match recommended practice.

questions.stem: Regulatory considerations for furosemide use in EIPH include:

options.label: A
options.text: It is banned worldwide in all equestrian disciplines

options.label: B
options.text: It is banned in many racing jurisdictions such as the UK but allowed under regulation in the U.S.

options.label: C
options.text: It is freely permitted without restriction in all racing jurisdictions

options.label: D
options.text: It is only used in endurance rides

questions.explanation: Furosemide is banned prior to racing in several countries (e.g., the UK), while it is permitted under certain regulations in the U.S., making its legal status jurisdiction-dependent. It is neither universally banned nor universally allowed (A, C).

questions.stem: Nasal strips are used in EIPH management primarily to:

options.label: A
options.text: Increase nasal resistance and improve lung conditioning

options.label: B
options.text: Prevent dynamic collapse of upper airways and reduce negative alveolar pressure during high-intensity exercise

options.label: C
options.text: Deliver medications directly to the lungs

questions.explanation: Nasal strips help prevent dynamic upper airway collapse, which reduces negative alveolar pressure and potentially mitigates EIPH. They do not increase resistance or deliver drugs (A, C).

questions.stem: Evidence regarding the effectiveness of nasal strips in reducing EIPH is:

options.label: B
options.text: Mixed, with some studies showing decreased RBCs in BALF and others showing no significant difference

options.label: D
options.text: Only based on in vitro data

questions.explanation: Research on nasal strips is mixed; some studies show reduced RBCs in BALF, while others show minimal or no benefit, so the evidence is not unequivocal. Thus, options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.stem: Which medications have NOT shown proven benefit in managing EIPH according to the presentation?

options.label: A
options.text: Procoagulants such as vitamin K, aminocaproic acid, estrogens, and vasodilators like pentoxifylline or sildenafil

options.label: B
options.text: Furosemide and corticosteroids for concurrent airway inflammation

questions.explanation: Procoagulants and various vasodilators have not shown clear benefit because coagulation disorders and primary vasoconstriction are not central to EIPH. Furosemide and steroids for concurrent disease (B) are commonly used.

questions.stem: The MOST effective non-pharmacologic management strategy to reduce progression of EIPH is:

options.label: B
options.text: Resting the horse and reducing exposure to strenuous exercise

questions.explanation: Rest and reduction of intense exercise are the most effective nonpharmacologic measures to allow healing and prevent progression, even if unpopular in racing. Increasing race frequency (A) or restricting water (C) are detrimental.

questions.stem: Additional management recommendations for horses with EIPH include:

options.label: A
options.text: Ignoring air quality and concurrent diseases

options.label: B
options.text: Improving air hygiene (reducing dust, mold, ammonia) and treating concurrent cardiac or airway diseases

options.label: C
options.text: Restricting all turnout and keeping horses strictly stalled

options.label: D
options.text: Avoiding any diagnostics after an episode

questions.explanation: Good management includes optimizing air quality and addressing concurrent cardiac and airway diseases, which can exacerbate EIPH. Ignoring these factors or over-restricting turnout (A, C) is inappropriate.

questions.stem: The general prognosis for horses with MILD EIPH is:

options.label: A
options.text: Poor; most must be retired immediately

options.label: B
options.text: Fair to good with appropriate management and performance modification

questions.explanation: Mild EIPH often has a fair to good prognosis with appropriate management, and many horses can continue to perform with adjustments. It is not uniformly fatal or irrelevant (A, C, D).

questions.stem: In SEVERE EIPH cases (e.g., Grade 4) that continue strenuous activity, the prognosis is characterized by:

options.label: A
options.text: Normal lung function and career longevity

options.label: B
options.text: Progressive fibrosis, reduced pulmonary compliance, fewer lifetime starts, lower earnings, shorter careers, and common recurrence

questions.explanation: Severe EIPH is associated with progressive fibrosis, decreased compliance, reduced starts and earnings, shorter careers, and a high likelihood of recurrence if heavy exercise continues. Normal function or improved performance (A, C) are not expected.
